author: By Ignacio Gómez G
title: The Human Cost of Your Breakfast Banana
description: In June a Florida jury found Chiquita Brands liable for the deaths of eight men killed by a Colombian paramilitary group the company had financed.
content: Although several El Espectador journalists were killed in the 1980s and ’90s, many young reporters aspired to being on the staff of the storied Colombian newspaper at the end of the 20th century. I loved working there, despite the risks. After the Medellín Cartel bombed our headquarters, my colleagues and I rescued from the rubble the desk on which Gabriel García Márquez wrote his first stories for the paper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: What Across-the-Board Tariffs Could Mean for the Global Economy
description: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, has floated the idea of a 10 percent tariff on all U.S. imports, a plan that economists say could badly damage trade.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump blames the global trading system for inflicting a long list of ills on the American economy including lost jobs, closed foreign markets and an overvalued dollar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: To Lure Michigan Voters, Trump Campaign Stokes China Fears
description: JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, waded into a fight over plans by Gotion, a Chinese battery plant, to build a factory in Michigan.
content: For two years, a rural town in the middle of Michigan has been embroiled in a civil war over plans by a Chinese-owned electric vehicle battery company to build a $2.4 billion factory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz
title: The Big Border Change Harris Isn’t Talking About
description: A Biden administration border policy that has had a dramatic impact isn’t getting campaign play.
content: Good evening. Tonight, my colleague Hamed Aleaziz, who covers immigration, looks at why the sharp drop in border crossings isn’t playing a bigger role in the presidential campaign. Plus, I want to hear about your favorite books about politics. — Jess Bidgood
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Police Hope Dog Breeder’s Missing Dobermans Can Shed Light on His Death
description: The police in central Colorado are tracking down Doberman puppies to help solve the potential homicide of a local dog breeder who died last week.
content: The police suspect that a dog breeder found dead at his home in central Colorado last week was killed, and they are tracking down his missing Doberman puppies to help their investigation into his death, according to the Clear Creek County Sheriff’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: ‘No Barrier’ to Nuclear Talks With U.S., Iran’s Supreme Leader Says
description: It was unclear if Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s comments signaled any shift in Iran’s stance, but the country’s new president has called for an accord that would relieve Western sanctions against it.
content: Iran’s supreme leader suggested that his country would pursue nuclear negotiations with the United States, telling the country’s government there was “no barrier,” to discussions with the “enemy,” in a video broadcast on state television Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Giratikanon
title: Connections Bot F.A.Q.
description: Introducing a daily, personalized analysis tool for Connections fans.
content: We’ve launched a beta of Connections Bot, a new robotic companion to Connections. Want to know what it is and how it works? You’re in the right place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: His Siblings Gathered to Sell the Family Home. Then He Started Shooting.
description: Joseph DeLucia, despondent over the sale of the Long Island house where he lived with his mother, killed three siblings, a niece and himself, the police said.
content: For years, Joseph DeLucia cut a foreboding figure to neighbors in the quiet Long Island cul-de-sac where he lived his entire life with his mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: What to Know About the Rare Mosquito-Borne Illness Eastern Equine Encephalitis
description: The disease has caused one death in New Hampshire and the virus has also been identified in humans in neighboring states, health officials said.
content: One person has died in New Hampshire after contracting the mosquito-borne virus Eastern equine encephalitis, and two others in the Northeast have been infected this summer with the rare disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isobel Whitcomb
title: Is DEET Bug Spray Harmful?
description: Some worry that this active ingredient is toxic. Here’s what we know about its effect on human health.
content: Q: Everyone says that the DEET in bug spray is awful, but my own research seems to suggest that it’s well-tested and safe. Am I giving myself a little bit of cancer every time I use it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Economists Worry About Trumpflation
description: And why they may not be worrying enough.
content: My latest column is about how inflation is fading as both an economic and a political issue — which is good news for Kamala Harris and bad news for Donald Trump. Yet it remains quite possible that Trump will win. And if he does, inflation may become a major problem again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Telegram’s Loudest Defender: The Global Crypto Industry
description: When the messaging app’s founder, Pavel Durov, was arrested, he received a flood of support from a multitrillion-dollar industry that relies on it.
content: Shortly after Pavel Durov, the founder of the messaging app Telegram, was arrested in France on Saturday, the chief executive of the cryptocurrency company Tether called the situation “very concerning.” Crypto enthusiasts pledged to support Mr. Durov, posting the hashtag #FreeDurov. Others investors declared that the arrest was an assault on free speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Harris and Trump Embrace Tariffs, Though Their Approaches Differ
description: Both Democrats and Republicans are expressing support for tariffs to protect American industry, reversing decades of trade thinking in Washington.
content: When Donald J. Trump ran for president in 2016, there was not much love for tariffs in Washington. Many Republicans and Democrats believed that putting levies on imports created economic inefficiencies and that freer trade was the best recipe for growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Man Is First to Be Charged in New York With Wearing a Mask in Public
description: Wesslin Omar Ramirez Castillo was frisked and charged with knife possession after the police stopped him for wearing a ski mask.
content: A man on Long Island has been arrested and charged with possessing a knife and wearing a face mask in public, a milestone moment in the debate over whether to criminalize masks in New York State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson
title: Top Biden Aide Visits China to Reinforce U.S. Strategy
description: The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, will raise thorny issues like Taiwan and Russia with only months left before a new administration takes office.
content: Making another heavy push to work with China in the waning months of the Biden administration, Jake Sullivan arrived in Beijing on Tuesday for talks aimed at showing that the United States and China can manage their differences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, David E. Sanger, Clare Toeniskoetter, Michael Simon Johnson, Shannon Lin, Lexie Diao, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Pat McCusker, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The First Major Cyberattack of the 2024 Election
description: Iran is to blame for hacking into the Trump campaign and trying to breach the Biden-Harris campaign, U.S. intelligence officials said.
content: The U.S. authorities have repeatedly warned that foreign governments would seek to meddle in the upcoming presidential election. It now appears they were right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
title: Israeli Forces Rescue Hostage in Gaza as Strikes Kill at Least 20 Palestinians
description: A Bedouin Arab citizen of Israel was rescued after Israeli commandos found him alone in an underground warren, apparently abandoned by his captors.
content: An elite Israeli military unit rescued a frail and gaunt hostage from a tunnel deep beneath the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, the eighth living captive to be freed by Israeli troops in nearly 11 months of war and the first to be found alive in the subterranean labyrinth used by Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Halina Bennet
title: At Michigan, Activists Take Over and Shut Down Student Government
description: Pro-Palestinian protesters won council elections, and have refused to fund campus groups, like the men’s Ultimate Frisbee team, unless their divestment demands are met.
content: Students were braced for a stalemate. There was an Ultimate Frisbee team without money to compete, an airport shuttle whose cost to students almost doubled without a campus subsidy, and a ballroom dance team unable to rent rehearsal space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: The Election Is in 10 Weeks. These 3 Things About the Polls Keep Me Up at Night.
description: It’s important to remember how messy social science can be.
content: Sunday night was an unexpectedly exciting time in the Anderson household: Just after dinnertime, my husband got called and asked to participate in an election poll. I was in the middle of getting my toddler ready for bed when he rushed into the room, holding our baby in one hand and his phone in the other, now on speaker so I could hear the questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Niarchos
title: H.R. McMaster Doesn’t Think Donald Trump Is Very Good at Making Deals
description: A new memoir by the onetime national security adviser shows how the former president’s insecurities and weaknesses harmed U.S. foreign policy.
content: Recently on the campaign trail, Donald Trump has talked up his aggressive stance on China, positioning himself as a tough negotiator in a brutal trade war. But a new memoir by Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, one of Trump’s national security advisers, throws that narrative, and many other stories that Trump tells about his time in office, into stark relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman and Vishakha Darbha
title: The ‘Sad Missed Opportunity’ of the Democratic Convention
description: Kamala Harris needs to do more to assure voters on Gaza.
content: The Democratic Party’s recent position — or lack of position — on Gaza “feels like gaslighting to a lot of Democratic voters,” Farah Stockman of the editorial board argues in this audio essay. The party claims to value social justice and human rights, but when it comes to the ongoing conflict in the Middle East, she says, Kamala Harris “needs to do more, and she can do more, to assure people she’s going to have a more evenhanded approach when she becomes president.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: The Year Tom Cruise Gave Not One but Two Dangerously Vulnerable Performances
description: Twenty-five years ago, the superstar starred in “Eyes Wide Shut” and “Magnolia,” and opened himself up for the camera in ways he rarely has since.
content: “Eyes Wide Shut” had a blunt sales pitch: Cruise. Kidman. Kubrick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: R.F.K. Jr.’s Brain Worm Speaks Out
description: After digesting Kennedy’s thoughts, his motivations become clearer.
content: A lot of people have been wondering what Robert F. Kennedy Jr. can possibly be thinking, and I can say with confidence that no one is better positioned to offer an answer than I am.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Prosecutor Turned Politician: Could Britain’s Leader Show Harris a Path to Power?
description: Like Kamala Harris, Prime Minister Keir Starmer was a prosecutor before embracing politics. The two share a few other traits.
content: When Vice President Kamala Harris said last week in Chicago, “you can always trust me to put country above party,” it struck a familiar note in Britain, where the new prime minister, Keir Starmer, used much the same phrase throughout the Labour Party’s relentless march to power earlier this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy
title: Why Some Young, Undecided Voters Changed Their Minds About Kamala Harris After Her Speech
description: They were skeptical and even suspicious of Ms. Harris before the convention. Her speech shifted some of their thinking.
content: This summer, Times Opinion organized a new project to follow a group of young, undecided voters through the election, and we kicked it off just before the Democratic National Convention with a wide-ranging discussion about Donald Trump and Kamala Harris. The group had very specific opinions about Mr. Trump. The Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol was searing for many of them, some of whom were teenagers at the time, and they held Mr. Trump responsible. They called him a traitor, a narcissist, untrustworthy. Some worried he would fight another election loss.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Love Your Pigtails’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: 1986: When Jean left, I vowed never to feel that pain again, and haven’t been intimate since. I embraced drag: the annual Miss Fire Island Pageant, my friend Raven’s weekly La Cage show, more. Leaving Manhattan, I still returned to compete in Fire Island (24 times and counting). After reconnecting last year, Raven came to see me, then drove me to the airport. I smoked. Raven admonished me to see a doctor. “Promise?” Instantly, after 38 years, I realized someone cared. Doctors found lung cancer. Raven’s insistent “Promise?” might well have saved my life. It certainly has revitalized my heart. — Michael Givler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Yan Zhuang
title: Typhoon Shanshan Approaches Japan, Bringing Heavy Rain and Winds
description: Japan’s southern islands were forecast to receive the most rain. The powerful storm has forced flight cancellations and disrupted high-speed rail travel.
content: Typhoon Shanshan was churning toward southwestern Japan on Tuesday, bringing torrential rain and strong winds, forcing some flight cancellations and disrupting the country’s high-speed rail network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Harris’s Ad-War Message: Trump Is Pro-Billionaire, She Worked at McDonald’s
description: The ads, focused on cutting costs, are meant to win over voters who believe Donald Trump would be better on the economy. They also signal a shift in tone from President Biden.
content: Flush with cash and fresh off the Democratic National Convention, Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign is flooding the airwaves and the internet with advertising that is meant to combat an overarching weakness: Voters trust former President Donald J. Trump more than her on the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 19 New Books Coming in September
description: New novels by Sally Rooney and Richard Powers, a memoir by the first Black woman on the Supreme Court — and more.
content: An American agent infiltrates a commune of French environmentalists in Kushner’s philosophical rendition of the spy novel. The anarchists should be no match for the agent’s clever tactics, but her loyalties and opinions prove to be vulnerable after she meets the group’s mysterious leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A Bargain at the Opera: Philadelphia Offers All Seats for as Low as $11
description: Seeking new audiences, Opera Philadelphia is putting in place a pay-what-you-can model, one of the first of its kind by a major opera company.
content: In Philadelphia, a night at the opera may now be cheaper than going to the movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Man Is Charged With Arson in California Wildfire That Destroyed 13 Homes
description: The Thompson fire also burned over 3,700 acres and forced the evacuation of 26,000 residents.
content: A 26-year-old California man was arrested last week on arson charges in connection with the Thompson fire in July, which destroyed 13 homes, burned over 3,700 acres and forced the evacuation of 26,000 people, according to the law enforcement agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: 5 Ways to Feel More Connected, According to Dr. Ruth
description: In ‘The Joy of Connections,’ a book set to publish shortly after her death at 96, America’s best-known sex therapist offered practical strategies for anyone feeling lonely.
content: Toward the end of her life, America’s best-known sex therapist Dr. Ruth Westheimer stopped talking so much about sexual dysfunction and started talking about another topic often shrouded in shame: loneliness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: How the Politics of the Gaza War Engulfed the Melbourne Symphony
description: The orchestra faced criticism for canceling a performance by a pianist who spoke about the war. Now a top leader has departed and the ensemble has opened an inquiry.
content: The pianist Jayson Gillham was performing Beethoven’s “Waldstein” sonata and Ligeti’s études at a concert hall in Melbourne, Australia, earlier this month when the concert took an unexpected turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Why the M.T.A. Is Worried About Fare Evaders on Buses
description: About a million bus riders fail to pay the fare every weekday in New York. The transit system needs that revenue.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at the rise in fare evasion on city buses, and what officials are planning to do about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: 21 Questions for Harris
description: We’re asking unanswered questions for her potential administration.
content: Kamala Harris has largely avoided answering questions since her campaign began: She hasn’t participated in a town hall or given an extended media interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilya Lipkin and Jay Massacret
title: For a Night on the Town, Try Leather and Lace
description: This fall, men’s wear is all about embracing the darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Is This Concert the Gold Standard for a Green Gig?
description: Coldplay and Billie Eilish have tried to drive down carbon emissions while touring, but the British band Massive Attack has tried to take the efforts even further.
content: When the British band Massive Attack was halfway through a West Coast tour in 2019, flying from show to show, the rapper and singer Robert Del Naja had a moment of crisis. Given all the carbon emitted by moving the band and its equipment around, he recalled wondering: Can I justify this anymore?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Former Aides to Bush, Romney and McCain Back Harris Over Trump
description: The former Republican staffers’ support of the Democratic ticket reflects how former President Donald J. Trump has transformed the Republican Party.
content: More than 200 people who previously worked for President George W. Bush and Senators Mitt Romney and John McCain have signed a letter endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 27, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 27, 2024.
content: An article on Saturday about peace negotiations for the conflict in Sudan misidentified Lana Nusseibeh. She is the former United Arab Emirates ambassador to the United Nations, not the current one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why We Cover What Politicians Wear
description: For both men and women, clothes can be an important tool for communication. Often, there’s strategy behind the style.
content: Ever since Kamala Harris became the Democratic nominee for president, making her the first Black woman and the first person of South Asian descent to be nominated for national office by a major party, celebrations of the historic moment have ensued. So, too, have the related moans about how, because she is a woman, her clothes will be used to define and diminish her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Ex-Mississippi Jail Worker Arrested in Escape of Inmate Who Was Found Near D.N.C.
description: Ronnie Hunt, 32, who worked for the DeSoto County Sheriff’s Office, is accused of aiding the prisoner, who escaped wearing plain clothes and walked out of a door with no handcuffs or shackles.
content: A former employee of a Mississippi jail has been charged with helping in the escape of an inmate who was later found barricaded last week inside a Chicago restaurant less than a mile from the Democratic National Convention, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Sawed the Head Off a Whale and Drove It Home, Daughter Says
description: Three decades later, an environmental organization is calling for an investigation.
content: It is a violation of longstanding federal law to collect parts from the carcass of a protected marine animal if there are still “soft tissues” attached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: A Pianist Who’s Not Afraid to Improvise on Mozart
description: Robert Levin has long argued that Mozart would have made up new material while performing, and he follows the master in a series of dazzling recordings.
content: Cadenzas are a concerto soloist’s time to shine: the moments when the rest of the orchestra dramatically drops out and a single musician gets the chance to command the stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: Is This the Edinburgh Fringe, or a Wellness Convention?
description: Grief narratives were in vogue, and psychological maladies, too, at the annual Scottish arts showcase.
content: As I made my way to Scotland for this year’s Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the three-week arts showcase that finished on Monday, I felt a little apprehensive. A conspicuous number of shows were themed around psychological maladies. These included plays about grief, anxiety, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder and gambling addiction. I had thought I was going to a festival, but this sounded more like a wellness convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Pro-Trump Super PAC to Begin $60 Million Ad Campaign Next Week
description: The group, Right for America, has raised tens of millions of dollars but waited until the fall rush to air any advertising.
content: A super PAC started by supporters of Donald J. Trump is launching what is expected to be a $60 million advertising campaign to boost the former president’s campaign right after Labor Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: 2 Are Killed at Delta Maintenance Facility Near Atlanta Airport
description: Another worker was seriously injured in the accident at the facility’s wheel and brake shop, where wheel parts were being disassembled, Delta said.
content: Two people working at a Delta Air Lines maintenance facility at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport were killed and a third was seriously injured by an explosion in the facility’s wheel and brake shop on Tuesday, according to the airline and authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: This National Guard Crowd Likes What It Hears From Trump
description: Former President Donald J. Trump got a warm welcome from an audience willing to overlook his past tussles with the military.
content: They knew they probably should not have been laughing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeğinsu
title: Another Icon-of-the-Seas-Style Megaship? Make That 3 More.
description: Royal Caribbean and other companies are aggressively building over-the-top ships. “Today’s cruisezillas make the Titanic look like a small fishing boat,” noted one sustainability specialist.
content: The Icon of the Seas, the world’s largest cruise ship, drew as much criticism as excitement when Royal Caribbean launched it earlier this year, but the ship has been a hit among cruise goers. Now the cruise line is adding to its fleet of megaships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Marc Santora, Danielle Kaye, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Russia Pounds Wide Swath of Ukraine, and F.T.C. Fights Grocery Merger
description: Plus, the rock band Oasis is back.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: A U.S. Open Party So Exclusive, Andy Roddick Just Got His Invite
description: An opening-night gala featured celebrities like Lin-Manuel Miranda, Alec Baldwin, Anna Wintour and Mr. Roddick (who won the tournament in 2003).
content: “This isn’t my normal U.S. Open,” said Andy Roddick, the former professional tennis player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Barnard
title: If Liza Minnelli’s Jewelry Could Talk
description: Studio 54. Versailles. The Oscars. Some of the pieces worn by Ms. Minnelli have seen a lot.
content: The scene had all the subtlety of a sequined sledgehammer: Liza Minnelli, a performer who has often been measured against her mother, the actress Judy Garland, was lounging on a sofa beneath fluorescent Warhol portraits of Ms. Garland, Ms. Minnelli and her father, the director Vincente Minnelli.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: For Italian Tennis Stars, a Little Corner of Rome in the East Village
description: A Manhattan trattoria has become the de facto lounge for Italians at the U.S. Open.
content: The Wimbledon semifinalist from Carrara sat in the bar area with his family. The 69th ranked women’s player, a hard-charging right-hander from Rimini, ate in the main dining room with friends. Out in the back garden, the 31st best men’s player in the world, a rising star from Rome, chowed down with his team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: The Gender Gap Among Gen Z Voters, Explained
description: Claire Cain Miller spoke with eight young women supporting Harris, and eight young men backing Trump. Here’s what she learned.
content: There is a significant gender gap in the political preferences of Gen Z voters in the United States, as evidenced by New York Times and Siena College polls conducted this month in six swing states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Oasis Announces Reunion Tour After 15 Years of Brotherly War
description: Liam and Noel Gallagher’s 1990s Britpop band will play dates in Britain and Ireland in 2025.
content: In the list of rock bands considered least likely to bury their hatchets long enough to successfully reunite, the British group Oasis has always been near the very top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Hwaida Saad
title: Dread Lingers in Mideast After Israel-Hezbollah Clashes
description: For people across the region, any relief that the adversaries had stepped back from an all-out war mixed with fears that the conflicts in Gaza and Lebanon remained unresolved.
content: Hezbollah and Israel appeared to de-escalate after a major confrontation over the weekend, tempering fears of an all-out conflict in the Middle East. But for people across the region, any feelings of relief were undercut by a deeper sense of deadlock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Destination for Indian Cuisine in Queens
description: Oh! Calcutta opens in Long Island City; Grand Brasserie fills Vanderbilt Hall with Parisian flair and more restaurant news.
content: The louche collection of sketches by the critic Kenneth Tynan that opened Off Broadway in 1969 has inspired the name of this new restaurant in Queens. Ruhel Amin, who has Indian restaurants in Harlem and Williamsburg, presents dishes from Kolkata, including a Lake Market fish fry, vegetable cutlet, chapli kebab with minced lamb, and kosha mangsho, a goat curry here. Workhorses like butter chicken, rogan josh and saag paneer are also on the menu. The chefs are Sharmeen Rahman and Lisha Khondoka; both women have worked in Mr. Amin’s other restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Two Bodies Found in Rice University Dorm Room in Possible Murder-Suicide
description: A female student was fatally shot. A man who was not a student had a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the university president said.
content: Two people were found shot dead in a dorm room at Rice University in Houston, the university president said on Monday, in what appeared to be a murder-suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta and Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: A Look at Harris’s Polling Lead
description: Plus, looking for love in Shanghai.
content: The presidential election is less than 70 days away. This is what we’re watching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Man Dies After Boat Flips on Colorado River in Grand Canyon
description: The death of an 80-year-old man was the fifth fatality there in a month, officials said.
content: An 80-year-old man whose boat flipped on the Colorado River over the weekend has become the latest fatality at Grand Canyon National Park, the fifth in less than a month and the 13th person to die there this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Special Counsel Revises Trump Election Indictment to Address Immunity Ruling
description: Jack Smith’s filing, in the case charging the former president with plotting to overturn the 2020 election, came in response to the Supreme Court’s ruling giving former presidents broad immunity.
content: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday issued a pared-down version of an indictment accusing former President Donald J. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election, stripping out some charges and tweaking others to help the case survive the Supreme Court’s recent ruling granting former presidents broad immunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: ‘Free Speech’ Should Not Shroud Criminal Activity
description: Some early details suggest the issue here isn’t one of free speech, but of criminal activity.
content: The detention in France of Pavel Durov, the founder and chief executive of the messaging app Telegram, has sparked a loud outcry about free speech. Elon Musk has portrayed the arrest on his X account as an ominous threat to free speech, and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. referred to the app as an “encrypted, uncensored” platform and said “the need to protect free speech has never been more urgent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: A Popular Weight Loss Drug Is Getting a Price Cut
description: Eli Lilly will now sell cheaper vials of Zepbound, presenting a direct challenge to telehealth companies that offer compounded versions of the medication.
content: With high demand for drugs like Ozempic, and a limited supply, a novel marketplace has emerged to cater to customers who can’t access them. Dozens of telehealth companies offer online prescriptions for cheaper, compounded versions of these medications. These alternative drugs come in vials, with syringes to draw out each dose, and cost hundreds of dollars less than brand-name options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
title: In Eastern Ukraine, Terrifying Bombardment and Near Total Destruction
description: Powerful guided “glide bombs” have helped Russia raze entire towns with ever greater speed. “When you drive into a ruined town, it’s like hopelessness,” one soldier said.
content: In the darkness of the cellar in the eastern Ukrainian town of Toretsk, the soldiers did not know how close the Russian glide bombs were landing. But the sudden change in air pressure that accompanied bone-rattling booms testified to the bombs’ destructive force as they tore into nearby buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: For a New ‘Empire Records,’ Zoe Sarnak Set Out to Write a ’90s Anthem
description: The composer is breaking the rules of musical theater and finding an increasingly warm welcome this year for her rock sound. Next up, “Empire Records: The Musical.”
content: As a teenager in New Jersey, the composer and lyricist Zoe Sarnak was a star soccer player, earning her place in the Princeton High School Athletic Hall of Fame. Her position? “Center mid,” she said in a recent interview. “The one who runs the most.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In ‘Only Murders in the Building,’ This Actor Is Above Suspicion
description: For years, Michael Cyril Creighton hoped one of his small TV parts would evolve into something more. With “Only Murders,” it finally happened.
content: On a rainy morning in early August, the actor Michael Cyril Creighton sat in a dog friendly cafe on the outskirts of Astoria, Queens. With him was Sharon, his seven-year-old rescue, who is part Chihuahua, part Jack Russell terrier, with a soupçon of haunted doll. Another dog scampered over to their table. Sharon growled low in her throat and bared her teeth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Can We Be a Little Less Selective With Our Moral Outrage?
description: Here are some alternative focal points for outrage for college students from Columbia to Berkeley.
content: Of all the world’s injustices, perhaps the saddest is that so many of them are simply ignored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Adams’s Pick for Top Lawyer Is Grilled by Skeptical Council Members
description: Members of the City Council questioned the record of Randy Mastro, a former federal prosecutor and aide to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
content: After months of saber rattling between the New York City Council and Mayor Eric Adams over his choice of Randy Mastro to become the city’s top lawyer, Mr. Mastro finally got his chance to plead his own case on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: For Its Famous Clientele, Peress Was More Than a Lingerie Shop
description: For more than 90 years the Upper East Side shop served socially ambitious women, including Brooke Astor, Gloria Vanderbilt, Diana Vreeland, Barbara Walters, Madonna and many more.
content: As word spread that the specialty store Peress of Madison Avenue was closing, fans came to pay homage — and stock up on the beloved shop’s selection of mostly European lingerie, robes, socks, nightgowns, pajamas and slippers at 50 percent off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: A Fatal Knife Attack Puts an Immigration Spotlight on a German City
description: After the fatal stabbing, which prosecutors say was committed by a Syrian who was rejected for asylum, the city of Solingen finds itself at the center of a longstanding debate over migrants.
content: Two days after a deadly knife attack in the German city of Solingen, the youth wing of the far-right AfD party put out a call for supporters to stage a protest demanding the government do more to deport migrants denied asylum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: The ‘Beetlejuice Beetlejuice’ Reunion Reunion: How It Came Together
description: Michael Keaton, Winona Ryder, Catherine O’Hara and their director, Tim Burton, look back on the first movie, the “Day-O” scene and their ghost comedy’s afterlife.
content: If you wonder why it took 36 years for “Beetlejuice” to spawn a sequel, consider how complicated it was simply to reunite its busy principals for a video call last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: On Stonehenge and Mispronouncing ‘Kamala’: The Winners of Our Week 10 Summer Reading Contest
description: As our contest comes to a close, we honor both a video and an essay, and hear from students and judges about their experiences participating this year.
content: Our 15th annual Summer Reading Contest received 9,329 entries over the 10 weeks it ran. This week we crown our last collection of finalists, and honor two top winners, Ranvir Sharma, 14, in video and Aarushi Bahadur, 17, for her essay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Take the Wheel
description: Julia Hoepner makes her New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Moscow launched more than 200 missiles and drones across a wide swath of Ukraine yesterday, in what Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, described as “one of the largest strikes” of the 30-month-old war. Officials said four people had been killed and more than 30 others had been injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Who Are the Korean Cheerleaders Flooding TikTok?
description: Videos of baseball cheerleaders performing an ultra-chill dance routine have taken over social media algorithms, intriguing millions of viewers.
content: It starts with bouncy drum beats, quickly interrupted by the sounds of sneakers squeaking on a gym floor. Then a thumbs up comes into frame, swiveling up and down like a hammer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: When Your Child Is an Animal
description: The charged cultural conversation about pets and children — see “Chimp Crazy,” “childless cat ladies” and more — reveals the hidden contradictions of family life.
content: “Monkey love is totally different than the way that you have love for your child,” Tonia Haddix, an exotic animal broker, says at the beginning of “Chimp Crazy,” the documentary HBO series investigating the world of chimpanzee ownership. “If it’s your natural born child, it’s just natural because you actually gave birth to that kid. But when you adopt a monkey, the bond is much, much deeper.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Shaer
title: Why Is the Loneliness Epidemic so Hard to Cure?
description: Maybe because we aren’t thinking about it in the right way.
content: In the early months of 2020, as the Covid-19 pandemic settled over the country, a psychologist and Harvard lecturer named Richard Weissbourd approached his colleagues with a concept for a new kind of study. Loneliness, or the specter of it, seemed to Weissbourd to be everywhere — in the solitude of quarantine, in the darkened windows of the buildings on campus, in the Zoom squares that had come to serve as his primary conduit to his students. Two years earlier, he read a study from Cigna, the insurance provider, showing that 46 percent of Americans felt sometimes or always alone. In 2019, when Cigna replicated the study, the number of lonely respondents had grown to 52 percent. God knows what the data would say now, Weissbourd thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Kennedy Says Trump Will ‘Make Americans Healthy.’ His Record Suggests Otherwise.
description: As president, Donald J. Trump slashed protections for clean air and water and weakened school nutrition standards.
content: When Robert F. Kennedy Jr. endorsed Donald J. Trump last week, he recounted speaking with the former president about “the issues that bind us together,” including “having safe food and ending the chronic disease epidemic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla and Loren Elliott
title: With Dams Removed, Salmon Will Have the Run of a Western River
description: The nation’s largest dam removal project is nearly complete after a lengthy campaign by Native tribes to restore the river at the California-Oregon border.
content: The Klamath River was once so flush with fish that local tribes ate salmon at every meal: flame-roasted filets on redwood skewers, stews flavored with fish tails, strips of smoky, dried salmon. In the language of the Yurok, who live on the river among California’s towering redwoods, the word for “salmon” translates to “that which we eat.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump vs. Harris: ‘Unserious Man’ vs. ‘Untested Woman’?
description: Readers react to a column by Maureen Dowd about the presidential race. Also: Falling art prices; “loser pays” legal systems; free school lunches.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: 5 Fresh Takes on Summer Classics for Labor Day
description: Packed with sun-sweet fruits and vegetables, these easy recipes are perfect for any party.
content: The days are still warm enough to make this long weekend feel like vacation — even if school has already started — and these dishes lean into these waning days of summer. The truth is, end-of-season produce sometimes needs a little boost. Even though corn, zucchini and peaches remain abundant, they may not be quite as sweet or juicy as their July counterparts. Creamy spreads and sauces and other rich ingredients (yes, butter) bring out the best in them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What to Know About the Hostages Israel Has Rescued During the War in Gaza
description: Israeli forces have freed eight hostages in military operations in Gaza since Oct. 7, out of the approximately 250 abducted in the Hamas-led attacks.
content: The rescue of a hostage on Tuesday from southern Gaza brought to eight the number of captives the Israeli military has freed out of the approximately 250 abducted in the Hamas-led attacks last Oct. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova
title: The World’s Largest Wetland Is Burning, and Rare Animals Are Dying
description: In Brazil, wildfires have roared across the Pantanal, a maze of rivers, forests and marshlands that sprawl over an area 20 times the size of the Everglades.
content: Two jaguar cubs burned to death, their small bodies carbonized. Tapirs with raw, bloodied paws had been scalded by smoldering cinders. Nests of unhatched eggs from rare parrots were consumed by flames as tall as trees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: First Jan. 6 Rioter to Enter Capitol Gets More Than 4 Years in Prison
description: Michael Sparks, 47, was the first rioter to breach the Capitol and among the first to be confronted by the U.S. Capitol Police Officer Eugene Goodman.
content: The first rioter to breach the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced Tuesday to more than four years in prison, federal prosecutors announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: CNN’s Dana Bash to Interview Harris and Walz on Thursday
description: The joint interview, airing at 9 p.m. Eastern, is the first time the vice president will face sustained questions from a journalist since President Biden withdrew from the race.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has agreed to her first major interview since she became the presumptive Democratic nominee for president five weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Mexico Pauses Relations With U.S. Embassy Amid Clash Over Judicial Overhaul
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s proposed changes to the judiciary are at the center of a diplomatic fight with the United States in the last weeks of his presidency.
content: For months, tensions have been building in Mexico over the president’s sweeping plans to overhaul the judiciary, shaking the country’s political system and straining diplomatic ties with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Looking for Information on L.G.B.T.Q. Travel to Florida? Don’t Ask Florida.
description: The state’s travel website recently removed pages dedicated to L.G.B.T.Q. travel. Some Floridians aren’t happy about it.
content: For years, L.G.B.T.Q. people planning a trip to Florida could turn to the official website for Visit Florida, the state’s tourism marketing organization, for resources on where to go, what to eat and where to stay. While there are other resources for queer travelers, the site offered information about L.G.B.T.Q.-owned businesses that visitors could patronize as well as activities “appealing to a gay community looking for a sense of belonging and acceptance,” a page on the site once read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: How R.F.K. Jr. Went From Environmental Champion to Trump Backer
description: Kennedy’s former co-workers in the environmental movement aren’t surprised that he endorsed Trump, who has called climate change a “hoax.”
content: Last week, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., once a prominent figure of America’s environmental movement, suspended his independent run for the White House and endorsed former President Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russia Launches Deadly New Wave of Missiles and Drones at Ukraine
description: The bombardment that began on Monday could have additional significance, coming three weeks after the Ukrainian military’s incursion into Russia’s Kursk region.
content: Russia launched a fresh wave of pre-dawn missile and drone attacks on Kyiv and several other large Ukrainian cities on Tuesday, the second day of a deadly, far-reaching bombing campaign that comes as Moscow fights to fend off a Ukrainian offensive on Russian soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: ‘Twilight Love’: Shanghai’s Lonely and Retired Are Looking for Love
description: China has the world’s largest population of people 65 or older, and more and more of them are unattached.
content: For Shanghai’s lonely and retired, love is elusive. Divorced or widowed residents gather in a dating corner in People’s Park every weekend looking for a chat. They mill about an Ikea canteen on Tuesdays in search of some fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan, Hamed Aleaziz and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Judge Pauses Biden Administration Program That Aids Undocumented Spouses
description: Ruling in favor of 16 Republican-led states that sued the administration, a federal judge put the program on hold while the court considers the merits of the case.
content: A federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked on Monday a Biden administration program that could offer a path to citizenship for up to half a million undocumented immigrants who are married to U.S. citizens, ruling in favor of 16 Republican-led states that sued the administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Lowenstein
title: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump Are Shredding Basic Economic Good Sense
description: It’s worrisome to see the candidates talk down to voters.
content: At her speech on economic policy in Raleigh, N.C., this month, Kamala Harris uncorked a beautiful riff that slammed a certain policy proposal as nothing more than a “national sales tax” on the American public, one that would raise the price of “everyday products and basic necessities” and cost the typical family $3,900.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 444
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Aug. 28, 2024.
content: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level and if you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yuval Sharon
title: Opera Doesn’t Have to Be an Elite Art Form. Here’s Why.
description: If opera at its best aspires to a different world, then we need to cultivate an anti-elite approach to how it is created and performed.
content: Is opera a standard-bearer or a pallbearer of the status quo?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: 1 Million Cheat Bus Fare Daily, Foiling M.T.A.
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 27, 2024.
content: “If the transit system does not work and nobody plays by the rules, it feels lawless. It is lawless.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: A Terrific Adam Sandler Special and Other Stand-Up Shows to Stream
description: The star is in fine, filthy form under the direction of Josh Safdie (“Uncut Gems”). Hannah Berner and Langston Kerman also deliver standout hours.
content: When Barack Obama made a reference to the size of Donald J. Trump’s, ahem, crowd size, in his speech last week at the Democratic National Convention, he brought a category of lewd joke into the absolute center of the mainstream. This unlikely achievement owes a debt to Adam Sandler, who has been consistently committed to the art, at least since writing a dirty rhyme in a classmate’s middle-school yearbook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Rubin
title: 4,000 Miles, 6 Small Towns: A Whistle-Stop Tour of America
description: Most people who ride Amtrak’s Empire Builder route between Chicago and Seattle watch the heartland whiz by. Our writer hopped off to explore a few remarkable places you might otherwise miss.
content: “See America,” an old Amtrak slogan promised, “at See-Level.” And if you ride the railroad’s Empire Builder route from Chicago to Seattle and back, as I did recently, you’ll watch the scenery evolve, from city to suburb to small town to north woods to sweeping grasslands to Great Plains to sandy buttes to snow-capped peaks to sagebrush meadows to pine-lined streams to small town to suburb to city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Trump to Put Kennedy and Gabbard on His Transition Team
description: Mr. Kennedy and Ms. Gabbard, who had been progressive Democrats for many years, will join the former president’s sons and Senator JD Vance, his running mate, as honorary co-chairs.
content: Donald J. Trump plans to name his former rival, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., and Tulsi Gabbard, a one-time Democrat, as honorary co-chairs of a presidential transition team that will help him select the policies and personnel of any second Trump administration, according to a campaign senior adviser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla’s Rivals Still Can’t Use Its Superchargers
description: Elon Musk’s plan to open Tesla’s charging network is proceeding slowly. Nobody is entirely sure why, or when that might change.
content: Scarce and finicky public chargers are among the biggest reasons people hesitate to buy electric cars. So when Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, agreed last year to open the company’s well-regarded Supercharger network to vehicles from other carmakers, many drivers and industry experts celebrated the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Michael Henry
title: The Finest, Funnest, Most Freeing Footwear
description: Go ahead and wear your rubber sandals — even in New York City.
content: Flip-flops have remained one of the most reviled men’s-wear items. Tom Ford regularly inveighs against them, and fashion magazines make special mention of their ghastliness. But in Orange County, where I’m from, flip-flops function in a way that’s only suggested elsewhere: They complete a tableau of carefree, sand-speckled revelry — an endless, almost utopian vision of joblessness and idle bliss. Even the PacSun and Hollister ads, set in an idealized Orange County, are too charged with a manufactured spring-break debauchery to accurately capture the mellow SoCal lassitude. In the O.C., flip-flops were flimsy foot skis meant to help people reach a secluded surf spot — for hopping in cars or treading lightly atop sand dunes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: He Bought a (Miniature) Zoo
description: The painter Walton Ford has amassed dozens of vintage German animal figurines.
content: Every morning, Walton Ford wakes up in his West Village townhouse and sees a menagerie on the mantel. The 64-year-old artist, who creates detailed, large-scale watercolors of exotic animals, has spent more than a decade building a collection of vintage composite animal figures. (The term “composite” describes the linoleum-like mixture used to create toys before plastic became manufacturers’ medium of choice.) Only two main companies in Germany produced this now-rare product — typically no more than 2 inches high and 2 inches long — between the early 1900s and World War II. “If you’re an artist who studies animal anatomy, you are blown away by these things,” Ford says. “It’s like you have these little zoo animals in the room.” Many of the creatures’ poses will look familiar to fans of Ford’s art; he frequently works from photographs of them. The artist, whose sketches, watercolors and studies are on view at the Morgan Library & Museum in New York through Oct. 20, says that being greeted by the tiny animals each day reminds him “what my purpose is.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: Heat Deaths Have Doubled in the U.S. in Recent Decades, Study Finds
description: The finding comes as a late-August heat wave bears down on a significant part of the country.
content: As dangerous heat bears down on the central and eastern United States this week, a new study shows heat-related deaths across the country are on the rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Will Harris’s Lead Last? A Few Questions That Will Shape the Answer.
description: A certain kind of change candidate that is proving tough for Donald Trump to attack.
content: Kamala Harris has wrapped up an extraordinary month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Oasis: Timeline of a Sibling Rivalry for the Ages
description: When Liam and Noel Gallagher get together, hide the tambourines.
content: The Kinks, the Allman Brothers Band, the Jacksons: Every band of brothers occasionally bickered, even feuded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: On the Covid ‘Off-Ramp’: No Tests, Isolation or Masks
description: For many, Covid is increasingly regarded like the common cold. A scratchy throat and canceled plans bring a bewildering new critique from friends: You shouldn’t have tested.
content: Jason Moyer was days away from a family road trip to visit his parents when his 10-year-old son woke up with a fever and cough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler and Sofia Sokolove
title: How to Turn August Grilling Into Autumn Grilling
description: With the right gear — and excellent recipes — you can keep grilling well past Labor Day weekend.
content: It’s easy to think of grilling as a summer thing — the temps are warm, the evenings are long and you’ve got a pool party’s worth of people to feed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Mariah Carey Says Her Mother and Sister Died on the Same Day
description: Ms. Carey, who has spoken and written extensively about her complicated relationship with her family, said the deaths had led to an “impossible time.”
content: Mariah Carey’s mother, Patricia, and sister, Alison, died on the same day over the weekend, the pop star announced. It was unclear what caused their deaths or when exactly they died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: One Woman’s Quest to Map the Paris Flea Market
description: The world-famous stalls have plenty of vintage finds, as long as you know where to look and what to expect.
content: Most anyone who visits Paris and loves to shop will be told to visit the storied flea market — “marché aux puces” in French — which occupies five acres in Saint-Ouen, just north of the city limits. The problem, many visitors find, is that it’s impenetrable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Who Is Farhan al-Qadi, the Rescued Hostage?
description: Mr. al-Qadi, a member of Israel’s Bedouin minority, was working as an unarmed guard at a kibbutz near the Gaza border when he was abducted, a member of his family said. His family was overjoyed at his return.
content: Israelis on Tuesday celebrated the rescue of Farhan al-Qadi, who was taken hostage during Hamas’s attacks on Oct. 7. But none more so than his family, who raced through the hallways of the hospital complex where he was being treated to greet him as quickly as they could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘Only Murders in the Building’ Goes to Hollywood
description: The murder mystery comedy returns with more celebrities than ever but in a winking, self-aware way.
content: In its first three seasons, the Hulu mystery comedy “Only Murders in the Building” recruited an impressively starry array of guest stars — including Nathan Lane, Paul Rudd and Meryl Streep — to join the already stellar main cast of Selena Gomez, Steve Martin and Martin Short. Season 4, which starts on Tuesday, has even more famous faces, which can be overwhelming at times. But there’s a knowing quality to the way these celebrities are deployed: “Only Murders” has gone Hollywood, but in a winking, self-aware way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Scientists Have a New Theory About Why Orcas Are Attacking Boats
description: A pod of orcas damaged a boat and left its two-person crew stranded. It was the latest in a string of attacks that research suggests could be used for hunting practice.
content: The orcas have struck again — this time ramming a sailboat off Spain’s northwest coast, rescue workers said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
title: At an Israeli hospital, the rescued hostage tells his family about his ordeal.
description: Farhan al-Qadi, who was recovering in a medical center in southern Israel, told relatives and friends he had spent much of his captivity in darkness.
content: Farhan al-Qadi, the hostage rescued by Israeli troops in an underground tunnel in Gaza on Tuesday, told his friends and relatives that he had been held in the dark for a long time, often alone save for his guards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yussef Cole
title: Star Wars Outlaws Review: Return of the Ennui
description: The vast galaxy is filled with well-worn concepts from other open-world games. Finding excitement requires descending to the game’s black markets and gambling dens.
content: Star Wars Outlaws, an attempt by the publisher of Assassin’s Creed and Far Cry to plug the famous movie franchise into the tried-and-true formula of the open-world action-adventure game, is, unsurprisingly, huge. It spans a broad galaxy broken up into several systems, each featuring its own hub worlds with distinct natural biomes and identities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Man Charged With Tupac Shakur’s Murder Loses Bid for Release
description: A judge declined to release Duane Keith Davis, whose trial is scheduled for March, after a dispute over the source of the bail funds.
content: A judge in Nevada declined on Tuesday to release a man who was charged with the murder of the rapper Tupac Shakur after expressing concern that the money provided to bail him out from jail could be connected to a possible deal to tell his story in a TV series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Special Counsel Filed Revised Charges Against Trump
description: Also, Israeli forces rescued a hostage from Gaza. Here’s the latest from the end of Tuesday.
content: Federal prosecutors today issued a new version of their indictment accusing Donald Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election. The revised document stripped out some charges in order to help it survive the Supreme Court’s recent ruling granting former presidents broad immunity for official acts in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: How Democrats View Kennedy and Trump: ‘A Weirdo Campaign Just Got Weirder’
description: Democrats once seriously worried that Robert F. Kennedy Jr. would be a spoiler. Now, after his endorsement of Donald Trump, they see a political opportunity.
content: Democrats say they have a simple plan for discrediting Robert F. Kennedy Jr. now that he has dropped out of the race and endorsed former President Donald J. Trump: calling him “weird.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: To Stay Relevant, a Spanish Energy Giant Turns to Waste
description: Repsol figures that there is still life in vehicle fuels as long as they can be portrayed as low carbon.
content: In a narrow valley with steep sides near the ancient city of Cartagena, Spain, a team of 150 engineers has just finished building a plant that could be a game changer for Repsol, the Spanish energy company, and a bellwether for the transportation industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Troy Closson
title: Cellphone Bans in Schools? New York Is ‘Not There Yet,’ Mayor Says
description: Districts and states across the United States have supported restrictions on student usage, but New York City’s leaders are backing away from the idea because of logistical concerns.
content: Los Angeles became the largest school district in the United States to ban cellphones in June. Entire states, such as Virginia, Ohio and Minnesota, have moved to institute broad crackdowns on phones in schools. But not New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and John Koblin
title: Trump Suggests Debate Rules Are Set. Harris’s Team Says Otherwise.
description: The two have been tussling over whether microphones will be muted when a candidate isn’t speaking during the debate, which is scheduled for Sept. 10.
content: Donald J. Trump announced for a second time that he would participate in a presidential debate with Vice President Kamala Harris hosted by ABC News and suggested that the question of whether microphones will be muted when a candidate isn’t speaking had been resolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: A Mercedes-Benz Fire Jolts South Korea’s E.V. Transition
description: The government is aggressively promoting electric cars. But a dramatic blaze in an underground lot has left some potential buyers worried about safety.
content: The flames and smoke from a burning Mercedes-Benz electric sedan spread rapidly through the underground parking lot of an apartment complex in South Korea this month. The fire damaged almost 900 cars, and 23 people suffered smoke inhalation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Guantánamo Detainees Moved Amid Structural Problems at Showcase Prison
description: The military, which in 2021 disclosed its last major internal relocation of Guantánamo prisoners, declined to discuss this week’s security operation.
content: Undisclosed infrastructure problems forced the military to evacuate the prison housing the men accused of plotting the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and other detainees from the war against terrorism, according to Defense Department employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Tell Us: What’s Your Favorite Book About Politics?
description: Share your thoughts with the On Politics newsletter.
content: Summer is drawing to a close. A long weekend is upon us. And I know there’s only one way you want to spend it: with a good book about politics!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Vorenberg
title: Abraham Lincoln’s Wiliest Trick Should Be a Lesson for Biden
description: A model of how a lame duck can nobly serve the nation.
content: The Democratic National Convention is over. Kamala Harris has accepted her party’s ringing nomination. President Biden has been relegated to the wings, a lame duck before his time. What role should he play between now and January?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Angwin
title: Breaking Up Google Isn’t Nearly Enough
description: To end Google’s monopoly on search, the company should be required to disgorge its data on what we’re searching for.
content: Have you looked for a recipe online? If so, you probably found yourself on a blinking hellscape of a web page that was as long as an epic poem, but without any of the insight. First, you get the hokey story about the recipe’s origin. Then there are the videos. The irrelevant ads. The photos of each ingredient. The thousands of words are divided up into sections with headlines like, “Chia Seed Pudding Troubleshooting.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Israel launches a deadly airstrike in the West Bank, and other news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: hatchling
description: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word hatchling has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 26 in “Florida Turtle Nests Are Recovering. When They Hatch, Expect Mostly Girls” by Elizabeth Anne Brown:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Safety Agency Cites Lax Inspections and Federal Oversight in Deadly Helicopter Crash
description: The N.T.S.B. says a lack of F.A.A. oversight contributed to a 2022 helicopter crash in West Virginia, in which six people were killed.
content: The National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday that inadequate inspections and lax federal oversight contributed to a 2022 helicopter crash that killed six people in Logan County, W.Va.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: Save These Summery 20-Minute Dinners
description: Each quick recipe — for larb gai, chilaquiles verdes and more — harnesses summer cooking energy without relying on summer produce.
content: It’s easy to gush over summer food, to feel grateful for the generous produce and farmers that have eased our cooking lives. Thank you for the juicy spills of tomatoes and stone fruit, for the smell of basil leaves and melon rinds and for all the color and crunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: What We Know About the Telegram Founder’s Arrest
description: Pavel Durov has been detained in France, as part of wide-ranging investigation into criminal activities on the messaging platform he runs.
content: Pavel Durov, the Russian-born entrepreneur who founded the Telegram messaging platform, was arrested on Saturday in France, as part of an investigation by French prosecutors into criminal activities on the app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Hostage’s Rescue Shines a Spotlight on Israel’s Bedouins
description: The Bedouins of the Negev desert suffered painful losses on Oct. 7, but less attention has been focused on their plight than on some of the other victims of the Hamas-led attack.
content: Farhan al-Qadi, the hostage rescued from southern Gaza on Tuesday, is a member of the Bedouin, an Arab community marginalized by Israel that suffered painful losses in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 9 Surprising Songs Sampled in Classic Hip-Hop Tracks
description: Hear where moments of Kraftwerk, Enya, Herb Alpert and more ended up in producers’ deft hands.
content: Today’s playlist is a celebration of a tried-and-true method of discovering new-to-you music: identifying the samples in hip-hop songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Edgar Bronfman Jr. Drops Pursuit of Paramount
description: Mr. Bronfman had frantically put a bid together over the last week even as Paramount raised questions about his financing.
content: Edgar Bronfman Jr. abandoned his pursuit of Paramount on Monday, dropping his 11th-hour bid roughly a day before the deadline to submit a final offer for the owner of CBS and MTV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg, Gabby Sobelman and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
title: Far-Right Israeli Minister Draws Anger for Comments on Disputed Holy Site
description: In the latest in a series of provocations, Itamar Ben-Gvir agreed that a new synagogue should be built at the site, which Jews call the Temple Mount and Muslims know as the Aqsa Mosque complex.
content: Israel’s far-right national security minister has drawn outrage for agreeing that he would like to build a synagogue at a disputed holy site in Jerusalem that has long been a flashpoint between Jews and Muslims.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Revised Indictment in the Federal Election Subversion Case
description: Federal prosecutors issued another version of an indictment accusing former President Donald J. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election after the Supreme Court granted former presidents broad immunity for official acts.
content: Federal prosecutors issued another version of an indictment accusing former President Donald J. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election after the Supreme Court granted former presidents broad immunity for official acts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Eden Weingart and Asmaa Elkeurti
title: Connections Bot
description: See how you stacked up against other players today.
content: See how you stacked up against other players today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Ella Koeze
title: The Geography of Unequal Recovery
description: The U.S. economy has added roughly 19 million jobs in four years. But as of the end of 2023, 43 percent of counties still hadn’t regained all the jobs they lost in the early months of the pandemic.
content: The U.S. economy has added roughly 19 million jobs in four years. But as of the end of 2023, 43 percent of counties still hadn’t regained all the jobs they lost in the early months of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Oklahoma Primary Runoff Election Results
description: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary runoff elections.
content: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary runoff elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Israeli Military Rescues Eighth Hostage Alive From Gaza
description: Israeli soldiers and special forces found Farhan al-Qadi by chance as they were combing through a tunnel network in southern Gaza.
content: Israeli soldiers and special forces found Farhan al-Qadi by chance as they were combing through a tunnel network in southern Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Twitch Helps Brands Find Their Fans
description: How do livestreams help drive culture and brands forward? Streamers like Critical Role and LittleSiha reveal how they built communities on Twitch, and how brands can form authentic bonds with engaged audiences.
content: How do livestreams help drive culture and brands forward? Streamers like Critical Role and LittleSiha reveal how they built communities on Twitch, and how brands can form authentic bonds with engaged audiences.
source.name: The New York Times
